awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Computer-based co-reading for students with reading disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide an out-of-school reading tool to complement and reinforce the in-school work of special education teachers. In the US, over 3.6 million students are assessed with reading difficulties, but school districts face challenges in providing appropriate services, specifically due to teacher shortages and budgetary constraints. Additionally, the number of students receiving special education every year is increasing. This research seeks to benefit school districts by enabling current teachers to become more effective in several ways: students will practice reading independently and receive appropriate feedback from the technology, the lesson plans will be customized by the teacher for the individual needs of the student, teachers will have additional time to concentrate on teaching new concepts or providing individualized attention to resolve specific problems, and teachers will have digital data on student progress tracking. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) seeks to produce a prototype that students can use at home to improve their oral reading. This prototype will use a cloud-based infrastructure and end-user application to perform computer-based co-reading with the student.  The technology solution will: (1) validate the student’s reading accuracy and offer remediation when the student makes a mistake, (2) allow the students’ reading teacher to customize the reading experience and the remediation, and to monitor the student’s progress, (3) use engaging book content, (4) capture and analyze data including how the students’ eyes track as they read and this data will be displayed for the teacher, (5) capture audio of students’ oral reading, and (6) provide to the teacher with the captured audio, the corresponding text using automated speech recognition, and the students’ mistakes.  This prototype will undergo efficacy testing and customer discovery, receiving feedback from Directors of special education and specialized reading teachers, in order to confirm the acceptable integration with current teaching practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project, entitled BuddyBooks, helps grade-3 to grade-8 students with reading disabilities (e.g., dyslexia, oral/written language disorder and specific reading comprehension deficit) improve their literacy skills at home, while being managed between sessions by their specialized teacher.  

 

This project introduced a novel approach to computer-based co-reading with a child with a reading disability that will validate the child?s reading accuracy and offer remediations when the child makes a mistake.   The core innovation and technical challenges were the combination of diverse peer-reviewed research strands with Natural Language Processing, into an effective remediation system to improve the reading outcomes of children with a reading disability. These challenges made this a high-risk endeavor, but one that can have broad impact now that this project is successful.  This project advanced the knowledge and understanding in the development of educational products, demonstrated how diverse research strands and Natural Language Processing can be combined to produce a cost-effective system for improving educational outcomes.

 

We conducted multiple pilot studies to create a transformative prototype co-reading system to significantly address the institutional and individual challenges faced by students with reading disabilities and obtained the following results.  We found that students increased reading time every day, improved fluency by up to 24%, were engaged in active learning, and students report they look forward to reading with BuddyBooks.  We found that teachers valued time-saving features such as using the reading progress reports for federally mandated Individuals with Disabilities Education Act student tracking reports and that teachers confirmed that BuddyBooks? fluency charts and listening to a student?s audio recordings saves the teacher time, enabling teachers to provide more targeted and meaningful intervention.

 

The broader impact and commercial potential of this project is its three intended contributions: (1) help children with reading disabilities by improving their literacy, which will improve their long term education and employment outcomes, (2) benefit school districts facing a specialized teacher shortage and budgetary issues due to the increasing number of children receiving special education every year, and (3) expand participation of individuals underrepresented in STEM, specifically children with reading disabilities.  While this research can help more than 13 million children identified as having a reading disability, the potential societal benefit of our innovation is that children with a reading disability can improve their reading ability and become more likely to graduate high school or continue to college.  The lifetime economic improvement for just one child graduating high school is $1.3 million.
